div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express service for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesday for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways exprekss service to Khartoum.

Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for YAMBO, JEDDAH, SUAKIN MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: EGYPT AND THE RADICALS.
div.p: One of the most dangerous by-products -as the chemists say of the triumph of the Radicals at the elections of 1906 has, says the “Daily Telegraph," been the stimulus given to agitation in countries, under our rule of protection that demand “Constitutions." We do not refer to the Transvaal or Orange Colonies, however premature we may think the grant was, because each of these communities had already enjoyed complete self-government, and, at least so far as the late Orange Free State was concerned, had not abused its privileges. But the Indian subjects of King Edward, whose civilisation was far older than our own, had never, during their myriad years of history, either shown inclination or capacity for self government. As soon as Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman became Prime Minister, a fresh vigour was imparted into the demand of the Babu for a Parliament, or some kind of representative body, which would have been fiercely resented by our Mohamedan fellow-subjects, who are more prone to action than to talk. In spite of a mysterious and cryptic passage in the King's Speech, we have too much confidence in Mr. Morley's common sense to believe that his “doctrinairism” will ever lead him to try so dangerous an experiment that of giving a “Constitution' to India, Representative Constitutions, as people may learn from Tacitus, are almost the exclusive product of the Teutonic race, and have developed most successfully only in that branch of the race known, for want of a better name, as Anglo-Saxon. We do not for a moment suggest that the Latin races are incapąble of utilising the system. But they supply it in a far different way from that which is in vogue in Great Britain and her Colonies ind in the United States of America. It was in old Whig fallacy, inherited by their Radical successors, that if any country in the world was in trouble and difficulty, all that was necessary to prescribe was a replica of the glorious Constitution of 1688. "Cansing was captivated by this delusion, and he handed it in to Palmerston, who carried the idea to the point of extravagance. In the case of many of our Colonies—notably Cape Colony-we foisted a Constitution, a sort of miniature of our own, upon people who not only did not want it, but positively were opposed to the dangerous gift. This high-handed generosity was merely an exhibition of that British arrogance which asserts that what suits us, our sentiments, and our genius must be good for every other community on the face of the globe.

A deputation of Egyptian , malcontenta, accompanied by .certain Little Englanders, waited recently upon Sir Edward Grey to advocate concessions in the direction of self-government for, Egypt. Now countries mainly Moha medan are less fitted than almost any other for self-government. Their religion is against it, Lag Indian Mohamedans have frankly admitted. The short-lived Turkish Parliament was promising enough during its brief career, but it was in no sense representative. In Egypt an attempt to create a Parliament upon English lines would be predestined to complete and even grotesque failure. There have been, ag Mrs. Malaprop said, “many allegories on the banks of the Nile” since the Father of History recognised Egypt as a prehistoric country. but not one of them ever suggested that “self government” would prove a success. On the face of it the idea is inadmissible. Representative institutions imply 'not only community of thought and sentiment, but their discussion amongst all classes of the people, these conditions do not exist, and have never existed, in Egypt or in Morocco, which is a parallel caso. No doubt even the fellabeen, who have profited 90 immensely by British rule, have their prejudice against being governed by men not of their race and religion. But they have forgotten the cory. e, the corrupt administration of justice, the unfair taxation to which their fathers were exposed. If we established "representative government" in Egypt, the Pashas would recover their old ascendency, and the fellah would suffer as he suffered before we intervened. It is said that Sir Edward Grey gave a sympathetic answer to the deputation, but the official statement issued last week prevents any false inference as to his interitions, Diplomatic etiquette and courtesy demand something from Foreign Secretaries. We may, however, rest assured that the Secretary of State gave no encouragement to a movement which not only threatens danger to the Empire, but absolute ruin to the people whom we have rescued from slavery and bankruptcy. Lord Cromer is a Whig of Whigs, and surely the Radical—oven, the Labour members-- might trust to him, with his splendid record, to do that which is right and best for the country he has ruled so successfully for nearly quarter of a century.

div.head: QUESTION IN PARLIAMENT.
Confidence in Lord Cromer
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
Lord Lonsdale asked. Sir Edward Grey what steps had been taken to impress the Egyptian, Government with the necessity of taking drastic action to deal with the Nationalist agitation.

Sir Edward Grey: I must give the same answer as I have given to requests from other parts of the House to intervene in Egypt in matters in which the Government have fall confidence in the discretion of his Majesty's Representative and do not propose to send - special instructions on this subject." In a letter to the "Times," - Sir Christopher Farness (Liberal) dissociates himself with the unwise policy pursued in Egypt and in Parliament by Mr Robertson, and concludes by asking Mr. Robertson and those thinking with him whether they suppose that the British evacuation of Egypt would imply a free and autonomous Egypt. "Why, if Great · Britain cannot get rid of the Capítulations, - Egypt herself - cannot get rid of them. Therefore to a plain man it seems. something of a mockery to dangle before the eyes of the contented and primitive people of Egypt the immediate vision of British parliamentary institutions which are unfit even for sómne of the peoples of Europe, and surely most united to country where the Congress of the foreign Powers exercise a law unto themselves."

div.head: New Telegraph Line.
div.p: It is stated that the Government has decided to make, a new telegraph line between Alexandria, Marsa Mátrouh, and Salouin.

div.head: Teaching In Arabic.
div.p: The Ministry of Education is said to be drawing up a draft decree according to which any pupil who cannot undergo his science examination in English or French will have the option of passing in Arabic.

div.head: The Reform of the Cadres.
div.p: It is stated that, the work of the two specialists charged to draw up, a new law concerning the reform of the cadres of the Government personnel is almost concluded, and that a part has just been sent to the Government.

div.head: Alexandria Athletic Club.
div.p: Mr. M. Blythman having resigned the secretaryship of the Alexandria Amateur Athletic Club, Mr W.M. Chevalier has been appointed in his stead and communications should be addressed to him c/o Messrs. Carver Bros - and Co., P.O. Box 388. ,

div.head: Fire in the Attarin.
div.p: Fire broke out at an early hour this morning in a wine shop in the Attarin quarter. The Fire Brigade were early on the scene and soon extinguished the outbreak before any very serious damage was done, although, owing to the inflammable nature of the shop's contents, the fire threatened to assume serious proportions.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive gave audience yesterday to H.H. Prince George of Brunswick, and afterwards called ûpon the Prince at Ghezireh.
His Highness also gave audiences to Mr. Henry Barker, Norwegian Consul 'at Alexandria, and to Scherabati Bey.

div.head: ALL SAINTS', CAIRO.
div.p: A meeting will he held at the British Agency on Thursday next at 6 p.m. in order to discuss the question of the appointment of a new incumbent of All Saints' Church. All members of the English community who are interested in church matters are invited to attend.

div.head: RESIGNATION OF SIR H. PINCHING
div.p: Sir Horace Henderson Pinching, K.C.M.G.. Director-General of the Department of Public Health, has just sent in his resignation, to take effect from the end of April Sir Horace has seen considerable service in Egypt, having been seconded for service in the Egyptian Army in 1888, from which he was transferred to the Sanitary Department in 1894, retiring from the Royal Army Medical Corps with the rank of major: He has held .the position he is now resigning since 1899.

div.head: THE WESTERN FRONTIER.
div.p: Said Bey El-Gazar, Sub-Moudis of the Behera Province, who had been sent by the Government to Tripoli in order to come to an understanding with the Ottoman authorities, on some frontier incidents, has now returned to Cairo and will hand in a report on the results of his negotiations to the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN CYPRUS.
div.p: A telegram from Cyprus states that free pratique is now granted to arrivals from Egypt.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND. AND INVESTMENT COMPANY
div.p: Mr. Reginfald Henriques, of the firm of Henriques & Henriques, has been appointed general manager of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company at a high salary. We congratulate the company on having secured the services of such an able commercial man as Mr Henriques.

Mr. Peacock will continue to manage the engineering portion of the company's business With two such able men on its staff, and with the strong local Board that has taken up the administration of the company, the shareholders may look forward to the speedy -development of the valuable properties which this company possesses,

A number of youthful Moslems and Cop's met yesterday morning at 10 o'clock in the Esbekieh Gardens, Cairo, in order to protest against the Coptic petition which has been submitted to Lord Cromer by some notable Copts, who expressed their satisfaction with the present administration of Egypt and deprecated the resolutions passed at the recent session of the General Assembly. The orators among the crowd took up a position on the bandstand. They included Salim Effendi Sid hom, Tewfi Effendi Habib, · Tewfik Effendi Azzouz, Lutfi Effendi Gomaa, of “Al Lewa" staff, Youssef Effendi Sidki, of Kasr el Aini school, Mohamed Effendi Farid, teacher in the Tah lirieh school, and Farid Effendi Kamel.

The orators denounced the Copts who had presented the petition to Lord Cromer, and declared there was no difference between Copts and Muslims. The British Occupation was atta sked. Europeans and Syrians were abused

A Parliament was demanded, and words of scorn were heaped upon the members of the Legislative Council for so poorly representing the people of Egypt. The character of the native Égyptian was praised in poetic terms. - Some speakers claimed the immediate institution of a Parliament, while others held that the University ought to take precedence of the grant of a Constitution. Another speaker declared that the British Occupation had resulted in draining the natives of their riches and leaving them barefooted and naked.

Foreigners had entered into possession of their properties and genuine: Egyptians were growing unfit to institute a parliament. Another speaker exclaimed that the only true natives of Egypt are the Copts, who are descendants of the Pharaohs, and the Moslems. The Government, the Occupation, and all the other elements of the population are their enemies. The most violent speeches were received with great applause, and the more fanatical the speakers were, the greater was the applause with which their harangues were received .

Tewfik Effendi Azzouz, who was especially remarkable for the way he stirred up his hearers against Europeans and Syrians, made an unfortunate mistake by venturing to deal with a very delicate historical problem. He referred to the epoch when the Muslims entered Egypt and were welcomed by the native Christians, and he declared that the Egyptian Muslims were the children of those Cupts who embraced Islam. A number of those present did not relish these allusions at all and the speaker's unfortunate references to a very ticklish subject were greeted with some very violent expressions of dissent, and some very gross criticisms were passed on his excursions into the past.
There was some tumult at the close of the meeting but fortunately, everything passed off happily and the audience were promised that another meeting would be held at a subsequent date.

div.head: MILITARY TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The parade ground .at Abbassieh was looking its best on Thursday afternoon, when all the world and his wife turned out to be present at one of the last big functions of .the season, the Egyptian Army, Military Tournament. Tents had been erected at the rear of the ground, and flags and pennons were flattering in the breeze, while the brilliant sunshine flooded everything with colour and gratefully tempered the cool breeze. Sir Reginald and Lady Wingate' were early on the scene, and the proceedings of the afternoon commenced with great promptitude when quite a number of people had arrived and were in their places. By four o'clock it as scarcely possible for late arrivals to ee what was going on within the ropes; and soon after H.H. the Khedive with his entourage had taken their places in the tent, there was *, general movement in the direction of the tea buffet. Lady Cromer arrived about 3.30; and among others who were present were · Sir John and Lady Rogers, Sir Vincent Corbet, Lady Newborough, Lady Vivian, Sir John Harrington, the Count and Countess Hollenstein, Mr. and Mrs. Findlay, Major General and Mrs. Bállock and Miss Bullock, Lady Hemming, Mr. and Mrs George Royle, Mrs. Maclean, Col. and Mrs. Gordon and Miss Mitchell, Col. and Mrs. Campbell, Mr. and the Misses. York, Mr. Carter Wilson, Mrs. Bayley, Mrs. Barnard, Mrs. and the Mieses Moroom, Capt. and Mrs. "Blakeney. Capt. and Mrs Clifford Hall, Countess Morice Bey, Capt. and Mrs. Morgan, Mr. Randolph Beren , Major and Mrs. Elgood, Moberley Bey and Mrs. Moberley, Mr. and Miss Farnell, the Misses Hyde Pago, Mr. and Miss Alan Joseph, Capt. and Mrs. Schreiber and Miss Hurley, Col. and Mrs. Dr mmond Hay, Mr. Whitworth Jones, Mr. and Miss dé Bilinsky, Dr. and Mrs. Maddon, Miss James, - Miss Johnston, Miss Beddors, Dr, and Mrs. Phillips and Miss Coxon, Mr and Mrs. Tatton Brown, Sir James and Miss B'yth, Mrs. Rome.

div.head: A TERRIBLE STORY FROM BEYROUT.
div.p: We have received information from Beyrout to the effect that considerable alarm has been caused by one Selim Mubarek, a bravo of the Lebanon, who ran amok a few days ago and killed eight Moslems He first visited a quarry where a number of workmen were engaged, called on the Drugs and Christians to stand clear of the Moslems, and then shot down fur unfortunate mėn with big revolver. After killing two or three more Moslems he made for the frontier of the Lebanon province, but was stopped and summoned to surrender hy a party of the Militia (Christians). He refused and s rots were exchanged. A soldier was killed and Mubarek fell wounded with strength enough to draw from his belt a phial of poison with which he took his life. Such was the end of a witless savage who might by his shameful tarbarity have provoked a religious outbreak costing the lives of hundreds.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).

Beyrout, March 19 Although Beyrout has been accustomed of late to bloodshed and rioting, yet this time it has received an unusual shock in a rapid series of murders of a most Tionstrons kind. Selim Mubarek, a well known contrabandist and outlaw, after hæving Leen closely tracked by the authorities, fled to

damerica some time back together with a few other fugitives of his stamp. Unfortunately the love of home, or perhaps rather the love of indulgence in illicit acts unhampered by a vigilant and strict law, brought them home again. It is said that Selim, not during to land at Beyrout for fear of being discovered, managed to disembark at Sour, but his notoriety seems to have been such as to betray him even there and to procure him some rough handling, from which he, however, managed to escape into the interior.

Two days ago he stole into Beyrout and together with his comrades he had a bont at a tavern in one of the Christian quarters. Arac seems to have stirred his worst instincts, and in going out he met two Moslems-tombac

vendors--whom, without the least provocation, he shot, killing one and wounding the other dangerously. This cool-blooded murderer then went his way bent on his Satanic mission. Meeting again four Metualis engaged in breaking stones for the repair of the roads he, smarting perhaps under the humiliating recollection of his ill-treatment at the hands of their Shiite brethren of Sour, shot the four of them, killing again three and severely wounding the fourth. He then Aed pursued, as it vere, by the curse of Cain, and meeting a Druge baker he shot him stone dead, where upon the baker's wife sent.p a cry of alarm which brought a band of Lebanese soldiers immediately to the spot.

As he was being hotly pursued Selim turned round and shot one of the gendarmes, but the bullet only grazed the cheek of the latter. Another gendarme took good aim and fired et the fugitive criminal, bringing him down at last to the ground. His body was then brought Liato town and exposed in the seraglio to inspire terror into the hearts of intending evildoers, and perhaps also to appease the rising wrath and revengeful spirit that was Eiving signs of bursting amongst the Moslem Table As ill-luck would have it, the Lebanese soldier that shot the murderer is a Druse Had 1.e been a Christian the Moslems would have seen much more appeased. As it is they could 110t help giving went to the Turking spirit of 1ovenge in their hearts by shooting an innocent Christian the next day, and the wound is reported to be fatal.

div.head: FUSION PROPOSALS ACCEPTED.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the National Hotels and Residences Company was held on Thursday to consider certain proposals made by the promoters of a new English hotel company in regard to fusion with the National Hotels and Residences, and, if approved, to give the board the most extended powers to accept and pass the arrangements relative to the figion and its being carried out. M. Antoine Bey Sabbagh, Chairman, presided, assisted by Me Colucci.

A report of the board of directors, drawn up by Me. Colucci, was read giving the necessary details in regard to the fusion proposals, acconrding to which the fusion with the English company would be of great advantage to the Nacional Hotels. The new company intends to open hotels at Luxor, Assouan, aud Alex andria, which would allow of their retaining their guests during the whole of their stay in Egypt. As the National Hotel cannot do this now that would be the principal advantage of the combination."

The company, to be formed would have a capital of £400,000 to £600 000, divided into shares of £l each and a proportion of 10,000 to 15,000 founders' shares. Shareholders of the National Hotels would receive four shares of the new company against ono of theirs and the holders of founders' shares one for every ten old (25th). The difference between the new shares and the old, viz., 24 per cent , will be paid in cash.

The proposals of the board were agreed to and the board was invested with the powers just for, the hope being expressed that the holders of founders' shares would receive founders' shares in the company in the proper proportions between the number of such shares created and the amount of the capital, and that moreover the shares of the new company should be fully paid up within a fixed period after its formation.

A glorious day and the prospect of a good lunch before the function of the afternoon attracted many people out to Mena House on Friday morning ; for gymkhanas there have been rare of late though they are always popular entertainments There were several large parties at lunch in the beautiful dining hall. Extra tables had been arranged in the adjoining ante-room, and despite the numbers a, most admirable meal was served with utmost promptitude. Amongst those who had guests with them, or had come out from Cairo in time for lunch,were Mrs Wood, Mahmoud Bey, Capt. C. Leigh, Lord Hastings, Mrs Eddy,
Mr. Randolph Berens, Mr. A. Nungovich, - Mrs. Black, Mrs. Duffin, Mr. and Mrs. Duveen and Hassim Bey

The Gymkhana was timed to commence at 2.45 and by that hour there was a goodly attendance on the ground, the early-comers lucky in being able to secure seats in the shelter of the small - grandstand. The band of the Inni-killing Fusiliers was in attendance with a most excellent programme of music, and after the arrival of the first tram after lunch the crowd of * onlookers was swelled to goodly, proportions. Amongst those present on the ground we noticed Prince Benya of Siam, Lord and Lady Hastings, Major and Mrs. Knight, Col and Mrs. Ludlow, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, the Misses Lyon Campbell, Mrs, and the Misses Coles, Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank, Miss M. Hickley and Miss Moss King, Capt. Trefusis, Capt. Carey, Miss Rigden; Mrs. de Behr and Mrs. Charlton, Mrs. Cook, Mrs and Mias Kingsford, Mrs. Eddy, Sir Eyre and Lady Coote, Miss Humming, Mrs. Wilding, Mrs. Maron and the Misses Morcom, Mr. Fitzgerald, Mr Trimen, Mr. A. de Bilinski, Mr. Dickenson, Mrs. Scott Dalgleish, Miss Molloy, Mr. Pooley, Mr. Stevens, Mr. Bateman, Mme de Vries and many others.

The Mera House Stäkes, a donkey race for gentlemen, was the first on the programme and was run well up to time. There were nine entries, the steeds being ridden without bridles. ‘After one false start the nine got well away, the winners being Mr. C. W. Hemp and Mr. G. McConnell.
The second event, the Gentlemen's Hack Race, distance half mile, was won in excellent style by Mr. Goodchild, Mr. Hicks, who was riding a horse of Mr. Stevens, coming in second.

Two ladies and five gentlemen entered for the Egg and Spoon Race, Miks Farrer, who was 80 well known last winter, promising to be well to the fore, but being overtaken by Mr Hemp just before reaching home!
That last-mentioned lady was more fortunate in the Ladies' Hack Race, distance three furlongs, making an easy win, Miss James coming in second.

There were eight entries for the Bedouin Camel Race, ridden by natives, which was quite one of the most interesting events of the afternoon. The animals, which were in the pink of condition, had to kneel at the starting point ; and there was wild excitement as they gathered themselves upstand started on their wild career, one or two of them objecting strongly to sticking to the course so conveniently flagged out for them. The winner, a magnificent animal, came romping home with many gruntings and grousings at his prowess, many lengths before the others.

The interval for tea was a welcome interruption, the hot gun and the desert air, being excellent thirst-producers ; and for some time the crush in the tent resembled that of the black hole of Calcutta and the rush for fluid refreshment was hard to satisfy. . There were seven or eight entries for the Mena Cup for Arab hacks, Mr. Goodchild getting a good start with Capt. Leigh behind him. Mr. Michaelides, however, soon overtook them ; and these three came along in a bunch till the last furlong, when Capt. Leigh, who was riding the favourite, a horge belonging to Capt. Holland, forged ahead to the front and took first place ; Mr. Michaelides making a good second on I'r. Wakeling's horse

The Donkey Derby had eleven entries, two of which were ladies, these having the honour and glory of distancing all the gendemen, Miss Farrer again coming in-first with Miss Eddy close behind her. There were but few competí. tors for the last event, the throwing of the tennis ball, Miss James, who had chosen Capt. Carey as her partner, being more successful than Miss Farrer, who had selected Mr. Hemp to aid her in the competition.

The prize-giving took place on the verandah of the hotel, the little son of Mr. Klinger making the presentations. They consisted of. very pretty and many of them very useful articles, mostly in silver ; though perhaps the most to be desired, from a woman's point of view, being the dainty enamel pendant and chain, and the ' enamelled' brooch of Egyptian design with the ibex wings, which were presented to Miss Farrer and Miss James for their success in the Ladies Hack Race.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: It is proposed to hold an open tennis tournament at the Alexandria Sporting Club, to commence on the 29th April and finish on Saturday, the 4th May, when the following four events, all open, will be contested -- No. 1 Men's Singles No. 3 Ladies' Doubles No. 2 , Doubles No. 4 Mixed Doubles

Competitors must be readı to play on each or any afternoon during the above mentioned time. The tournament will take place only provided that at least the following minimum number of ent ies are received : In event No. 1, twelve entries, No. 2, eight, Nos. 3 and 4; six entries each. Any player wishing to enter for this to mnament is requested to send in his name to the H n. Tennis Secretary, Alexandria Sporting Club, Alexandria, as soon as possible before the 20th in-t., after which date definite details will be announced in our columns.

Prince Mohamed Aly, saya "Al Akhbar," is going shortly to Constantinople where he will stay with the Khedive Mother. Afterwards he will go on a voyage to Australia, New Zealand, and Tasmania. His Highness will be accompanied by Aly Bey Shakin, Second Master of Ceremonies.

According to the latest news from Paris, the French Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo, M. Klobukowski, will shortly be appointed to a more important post.- M. Klobukowski, who is a personal friend of M,. Pichon, received his present appointment frota the former French Cabinet. He had been in Cairo but a short time when he was summoned to undertake a mission to Abyssinia. -
Judge Bourgueil, who had been appointed successor to Judge Prunières at the Cairo Mixed Courts, will not come to Egypt on account of the ill-health of his wife.
The annual salary of Ahmed Bey Afifi, honorary president of the Mixed Appeal Court, has been raised to LE. 1,000.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place quietly in May, between Captain A.W. Jennings Bramly, 20th Hussars (seconded for service with the Egyptian Army), - son of the late Mr. J.R Jennings Brainly, R.H A., and Mary Dorothy (Dora), daughter of Mr. H C. Steel, of -27, Kingsgate-street, Winchester.
Captain S. C. Halse, . R.G A., accompanied by Mrs. Halse, is leaving Port Said on Monday by the P. & O. steamer Isis on transfer home.
Lieut. Sir W. B. Bartellot, Bart., 3rd Coldstream Guards, has been granted leave of absence from the 25th inst, to July 9, ·

Miss Julie Critten, whose services as palmist have been in great request this spring, is leaving for England by the P. & O, Marmora. Those who wish to consult her this next week will find her at Shepheard's every afternoon between the hours of 2.30 and 6,90, or at other hours in the day by appointment.

The passengers by the train de luxe for Upper Egypt on Thursday , night were : Mr. and Mrs. Thurtson, Mr, and Mrs. Schmuck, Mr. George Van Zandi, Mr A. Schmuck, Mrs, and Miss Frost, Miss A Schwarz, Mrs. Richardson, Rev., Webster, Rev. Wold, Mr, and Mrs. Kobegard, Miss Ritter, Misg Stillwell.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port-Said, are: Mr. N. Kean, Mr. and Mrs. S. Stein, Mr, W: Stork, Mr. S. Fox. Mr. Eeman, Mr. J. Rooff, Mrs. Willmoor. Miss Caillard, Mr. Gould, Major General Ferting, Mr. P. Du Boulay, Mr. R. Du Boulay, Mr W.Joseph, Mr R Delany, Mr P. Rubely, Mr, and Mrs. F. Anderson, Mr. N. S. Reyn. tiens, Mr.. Handford, Dr. Cannell, Aly Bey Bahgal, Mr. Yeoman, Mr. Labbock, Mr. K. Hoyle, Mr. J. H Chinn.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.) La vogue est toujours aux * Nile Land, Estates, United, Ritz, Land Investment and Building, Arditi, Levico, Comptoir, Delta Land et Casa di Sconto. A joindre exceptionnellement dans le groupe animé la National Bank, qui d'ailleurs fléchit à 26 3/8.

A part l'Arditi, la Levico et la Land Investment & Building qui sont fermes aux prix respectifs de 1 7/16, 1 3/8, et 7/8, les autres perdentdu terrain : la Cassa di Sconto revient à 228 1/2, 225 et 215, la Delta Land à 3 9,16 vende ors, la Nile Land à 29 1/4, les Estates à 2 3/32, la nouvelle action Comptoir à 6 3/4, l'United à 1 1/8, les Ritz à 3 5/32.

En baisse également les Lots Taros à 152, les Nungovich à 28 1/2, l'Investment à 1 1/16 vendeurs, l'Urbaine à 7 1/4 l'ancienne et 6 3/4 la nouvelle, l'Union Foncière à 5 7/8, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien à 5 15/16, et l'Aboukir à 39/9.

Par contre, il y a reprise da Crédit Foncier à 340, de l'Anglo American Nile à 4 3/4, de l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail à 30/3, des Splendid Hotels à 4 11/16, du Banco di Roma a 115, des fondateurs. Allotment a P.T. 105 et de l'Helouan à 13/16.

div.head: TRANSVAAL PARLIAMENT
ELECTION OF SPEAKER.
div.p: At the last moment the Volkites proposed Mr. Beyers, an ardent Boer, as Speaker. He was elected by 53. votes to 22. Yesterday's proceedings were frequently interrupted by cries for Dutch and counter eries for English.
The Transvaal Council has passed the Asiatiç Bill. Lord Selborne has reserved the King's approval. :
The Assembly has adjourned till 14th June.

div.head: DEAR MONEY.
div.p: RISE IN FRENCH BANK RATE.
The rise in the French Bank rate has gur: -prised and disquieted the Stock Exchange. It is interpreted as an indication that money may continue dear for a long time. (Reuter)

div.head: THE WHITELEY MURDER.
div.p: RAYNER SENTENCED TO DEATH.
A verdict of the wilful murder of Mr. Whiteley was given against Rayner. He has been sentenced to death., (Reuter)

div.head: FIGHTING IN SOUTH AMERICA.
div.p: American marines have been landed at Trujillo, Laceiba, and Puerto Cortez (Honduras), in order to protect American interests in view of the continued heavy fighting between the Nicaraguans and Hondurans. - (Reuter)

div.head: RED CROSS SOCIETY.
div.p: The Dowager- Empress of Russia has given £10,000 to the Red Cross Society to be devoted to three prizes for the inventors of the beat means of relieving wounded. (Reuter)

div.head: PANTHEON FOR BERTHELOTS
div.p: The Government has decided on the inhumation of M. Berthelot and his wife in the Pantheon..
(Havas)

div.head: GAMBLING IN FRENCH CASINOES.
div.p: The Chamber has passed the law regulating gambling in the casinoes.
(Havas)

div.head: HOME RACING.
div.p: Grand National Steeplechass (Liverpool). 1.. Eremon ; 2. Tom West ; 3. Pat Lander. -Betting : 8 to 1 Eremon ; 100 to 6 Tom West ; 50 to 1 Pat Lander. 23 ran. Won' by 6 lengths. Pat Lahder was a bad third. . (Reuter).

div.head: ROUMANIAN RIOTS.
COLLISIONS WITH TROOPS.
div.p: Collisions between troops and peasants have occurred at many points throughout the country, resulting in numbers of casualties on both sides. 400 peasants forced an entrance into Jassy after the troops had killed or wounded several of them, and plundered several landowners' residences. Numbers of Jewish villages have been completely looted. (Reuter) A
BUKAREST, March 22.
The continuous spread of the peasant revolt is creating, uneasiness. Mobs are looting and buraing in a wholesale manner.. The attitude of the troops is not always satisfactory. (R)
BUKAREST, March 22.
The agrarian revolt in Moldavia is becoming more serious. The peasants have burned the town of Norohoj.
(Havas)

div.head: Egyptian Lignolite & Brick Company, Limited.

div.p: The Subscription list wilt open on 20th March 1907 and close on or before 27th March 1907 at 6 p.m. at the Ofloes of the Casta di Soonte e di Risparmio at Alexandria and Cairo.

Divided Into 49,760 Ordinary Shares of 81 onoh, and 3,000 Dotorrid Shares of the above Ordinary Shares 29,760 are to be presently issued, and of these 6,000 are payable as part of the purchase money for the various properties acquired by the Company as mentioned herein, one third of the balance or 8,260 are reserved for private subscription and Subscriptions are invited from the Publio at par form 16,500 Ordinary Shares of £1,
Payable as follows 2/6 per share on Application ; 7/6 por share on Allotment, and 10/- two months after allotment.

Share Warrants to Bearer will be delivered free of stamp duty to Driginal Subscribers upon payment of their Shares in full, but no payment in anticipation will carry with it any right to dividend on the amount 80 paid in advance.
Directors

ENRICO NAHMAN, Esq., Banker, Alexandria and Cairó. HABIB BEY HOMSY, of H. & L HOMBY, Alexandria, V.S. CELI, Esq. Contractor, Alexandria P. ARCOUDARIS, Esq., Engineer, Alexandria. HENRY GORRA, Esq , Engineer and Architect, Alexandria. CAV. GIUSEPPE G. MATTIOLI, Architect and Engineer, Alexandria JACQUES J. SUARES, Esq., Banker, Alexandria.
Bankers

Auditors
Messers: RUSSELL, KERR & WYATT, Chartered Accountants, Alexandria and Cairo.
Secretary and Registered Offices in London, W. A. WATERLOW, Esq., 25, Birchin Lane, London, E.C.
Factory In Egypt Paulino Quarter, Moharram Bey, Alexandria.
PROSPECTUS.

This Company has been formed for the purposes specified in the Memorandum of Association; and in particular (I) to acquire and take over the existing factory and exploitation of Lignolite and Lithite, now carried on by Messrs. Jaertues -Isolica & Co (2) to acquire and take over the existing fuctory of sand bricks carried on by Habib Bey Homsy' at Alexandria.
LIGNOLITE.

Lignolite is a product composed principally of saw-dust treated by a special process as to form a hard and impervious material possessing all the properties of wood and at the same time having a surface entirely in one piece, without joints or interstices and able to resist equally-fire and water. .

It is employed in numerous ways in the construction of building', for floorings, interior walls, etc., and apart from these uses it is anticipated that a groat future for lignolite will be found in paving the streets. An experiment has already been made in this latter direction by laying some paving of lignolite outside the departure platform of the Cairo Railway sta tion, where for the last two years it has shown satisfactory resistance. As a further experi. ment, a small portion of the road in front of the Municipal Building in Alexandria has been paved but has not given equally favorable results from various reasons ; however with the consent of the Municipality another trial is to be made under more favorable circumstances, and it is confidently hoped that the superiority of Ligriolite over all other paving materials will be shown.

The industry has already been flourishing for several years in Alexandria in an up to date factory, and the Company will acquire from the present owners, Messrs. Jacques Isolica & Co, the whole of the existing machinery and plant, as well as the Egyptian rights in the patents and trademarks connected with the invention The demand for Lignolite is a growing one, as is shown by the many orders received from the Egyptian Government and other administrations and individuals, and everything points to a. brilliant feature for the invention, and to a heavy profit financially... - The Company will take over from Messrs. Jacques Isolica & Co. all the existing contracts and trade debts at their value at the time of . the ratification of the agreement mentioned Lelow by the Company, and in addition Messrs. Jácques Isolica & Co. are prepared to guarantee to the Company the full amount of all debts due.
The following agreement has been entered into :

An agreement dated the 28th February 1907, between Messrs. Jacques Isolica & Co. and Mr. Enrico Nahuan as trustee.for the proposed Company of the other part, under which the Company will purchase ay from the date of the ratification of this 001 concern the industry and manufacture of lignite as carried on by the vendors, together with the benefit of all contracts in the course of being fulfilled. At the same time the Company will take over thu in machinery and equipment and the patent rights in Egypt hold by the vendors in the manufacture of Lignolite and Lithite, and the trade-marks connected therewith. The price to be paid will be £5,425, of which £5,000 will be taken wholly in fully paid up Ordinary Shares of the Company, and the balance of £425 in cash. The good will of the business is also included in the transfer and in consideration of this the vendors will have allotted to them 800 Deferred Shares of the Company, for which they will pay in cash.
Briek Manufactory.

At the present moment throughout Egypt, and more especially in Cairo, Alexandria, and other large towns in the Delta, buildings are rapidly springing up in increasing nuinbors ; stone, which has hitherto been used in the construction, is becoming more and more difficult to obtain, its y is becoming inferior, and its price is increasing. This explains the very considerable increase in the use of bricks in constructions at the present time, and at Alexandria alone it is estimated that no less than 75 million bricks are used annually, and this number is continually increasing. The ordinary brick of the country is made irregularly, presents a feeble resistance to crushing and is very easily broken in handling The 90-called European brick of good quality, manufactured also in Egypt, is somewhat rare and very dear. The real European brick brought from Europe costs more than three times that made in Egypt, and raises tremendously the cost of masonry work in buildings.

The brick made of artificial sandstone which, constructed by new methods, has shown such brilliant results, especially in Germany, is free from all the defects of the Egyptian brick, and possesses in an even superior degree all the qualities of the European brick. It is of pleasing appearance, regularly and perfectly formed, and resistance crushing weight of 200 Kilogrammes per sq. centimetre : it is further proof against all atmospheric influences, resisting the highest as well as the lowest temperatures, and suffering no deterioration from the effect of the sea air.

The manufacture of this brick is very simple and the roateriala necessary are abundant in Egypt. The time required is only 24 hours, as against the three things necessary before a clay brick can be delivered in Egypt, thus allowing a much quicker turnover of capital.

On a moderate calculation of the estimated sale of these bricks at 10 million & year a handsome profit can be made in the saving in their price over the European bricks. With slight additions only to the existing machinery the factory would be in a position to supply, as well as the bricks, other forms of ordinary bricks and stones, columns, cornices and squares of mosaic.

The following agreement hag been entered into :- An agreement dated the 28th February 1907, between Habib Bey Homsy of the one part, and Mr. V. g. Cell as trustee for the proposed Company, of the other part, under which the Company will acquire from Homsy Bey the brick factory and industry y carried on by him and his from the date of the ratification of this agreement by the Company, together with the patent rights in Egypt of the invention of sand bricks obtained by Homsy Bey. The latter will also undertake not to compete against the Company in Egypt. In consideration of the transfer as above, Homsy Bey will be allotted 400 Deferred Shares in the Company, for which he will pay in cash. The machinery and stock will also, be taken over by the Company as from the date of the ratification of this contract at a price to be fixed or if necessary settled by arbitration and paid for in enuh..

The remaining one third will be taken up by the subscribers to this agreement in the proportions shown below, and 3,800 of the Deferre 1 Shares will be allotted to them, as also shown below. both Ordinary and Deferred Shares being paid for in cash. 5

760. The Directors, with the exceptiòn of Mr. Areoudaris, are the promotors of the Compang,
nt get out above, as shown in the agreements above referred to. TEA Sub-underwriting contracts will be entered into by the underwriters with various person9.
There are in addition contracts of an ordinary trade character which the Company will take over on acquiring the businesses before mentioned,
The qualification of a Director will be the holding of 200 Ordinary Shares in the Company.
" Except as mentioned above no other shares of this issue will be issued as fully as partly paid up otherwise than in cash

* The provisions of the memorandum and Articles of Association with regard to the position of the Shareholders, division of profits, creation of Reserve Fund and remuneration of the Directors are as follows:

From and out of the profits of the Company which in respect of each year shall be available for dividends - a gum eq tial to 10% of such profits shali be carried to a special Reserve Fund The remaining 90% of such profits. shall be dealt with as follows :

· The holders of the Ordinary Shares are entitled (1) 'to a fixed preferential dividend at, the rate of 6% per annum on the capital for the time being prid up or credited as being paid up thereon respectively, such dividend to be paid as regards each year, out of the profits of such year, and to be non-cumulative, and to 60% of thé: surplus profits which in each year it shall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining after paying or providing for the above-mentioned Reserve fund and the payment of the said fixed dividend ; (2) to priority as to return of capital and payment off of arreare of . dividend whether declared or not up to the commencement of the winding up.

The Deferred Shares confer on the holders thereof, rateably and in proportion to the number of Deferred Shares held by them respectively, the right to 25% of the surplus profits which respect of each year it shall be determined to distribute after paying or providing for the above-m-ntioned Reservo Fand and the payment of the said fixed preferential dividend on the Ordinary Shares.

The Board of Directors will receive as remuneration for their services 15% of the surplug profits as . above, after providing for the above-mentioned Reserve and the payment of the said fixed preferential dividend. Such remuneration to be divided among the Directors' in such proportions and manner 88' they themselves may determine and in default of such determination among them equally.
In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Director shall also receive such further sum (if any) as the Company in general meeting may from time to time determine.

Any Director may be employed by or hold any office of profit under the Company, except that of Auditor of the Company, and may act either personally or as a member of the firm for, or render any professional service to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for SO doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as a Director. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra sers ices or to make any special exertions in going or resirling abroad · or in negotiating or carrying into effect any contract or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or to act as trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum or percentage of profits, or otherwise, ag may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition substitution for, his remuneration above provided. If any Director shall be appointed to represent the Company ag a Director of any subsidiary. or other company in which the Company shall be interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain. there.nuneration attaching to such Directorship for. his own use.
No promotion money will be paid, except as aforesaid.

The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of the Company down to and including allotment, including registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses, the cost of advertising and issuing this prospectus, but excluding stamp duty on share' warrants, will be paid by the Company, and are estimated at £2000. -

Application for shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the company's Bankers, Cassa di Seonto di. Risparmio, Alexandria and Cairo. If no allotment is made, the application money will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the surplus will be returned to the applicant.
The Director's reserve to themsel vog discretion in the allotment of shares. - Failure to pay an instalment on shares when due will render previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at 10 % of the shares offered. The whole of the present. 'issue of shares has, however, as stated above, been underwritten,
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon..

The above mentioned contracts or copies of these documents together with the print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association may by inspected at the provisional offices of the Company, Place Mohamed Ali, Alexandria, and at the offices of the legal adviser of the Company.
Copies of this Prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the name of flies and at the offices of the Bankers of the Company at Cairo and Alexandria.
Dated 16th March 1907.

div.head: Coton.
div.p: Malgré l'énorme erivie que nous aurions, par faiblesse humaine, de taquiner ceux que nous appellerons nos adversaires habituels, 1 . nous nous montrerons pour cette fois de bonne composition et les laisserons en paix : ils en. ont assez avec leurs déboires, sans avoir, nous, besoin de venir retourner la lame dans la pldie Et puis, après tout, le dernier mot n'est pas encore dit, et une manœuvre quelconque pourrait toujours survenir, pour nous donner tort, ne fût-ce que momentanément, et leur inspirer de nouvelles illusions, irréalisables comme finale, et par conséquent la prudence commande que nous nous réservions, pour le jour ou les faits nous auront donné complètemeut raison et auront justifié nos idées de baisse.........à moins qu'entre-temps nous ne pardonniong. toutes les attaques dont nous avons été l'objet de la part de certains haussiers et tous les sarcasmes dont on n'a pas été avare à notre égard.

Ce petit préambule donne déjà un avantgoût de ce que no s avons à dire ou de ce que nous allons écrire aujourd'hui ; aussi, nous ne - saurions donner de meilleur conseil à ceux qui rêvent encore les 25 et les 30 tallaris, que de
se contenter de la- lecture de ces quelques _ lignes pour s'épargner un peu de mauvais

sang, s'ils sont d'une nature-impression: able ! Nous tâcherons d'être modérés et de nous limiter à une simple relation des faits, mais il nous est impossible de garantir que nous saurops éviter toute appréciation de la situa-1 tion i pourrait leur déplaire !

La semaine que nous allons passer en revue, & commencé d'une façon qui ne présentait rien de particulier : La faiblesse dominait et la tendanee a semblé constamment peu brillante, mais en définitive tout le mal po r les trois | premiers jours a consiste en un recul des prix. de 11/32 de tallari, après que, en passant, nous avions touché 1/2 tallari.. .

Mercredi, les choses ont mienx marché et pour un inoment nous étions remontés, à 1 16 près, au cours de clôture de vendredi dernier, majs la finale de la journée a été que la perte totale était de 5/32,

Hier cependant, et après une ouverture plu*tot brillante, nous avons eu soudain un revirement et un mouvement, sensible de baisse qui a ajouté autres 3 16 aux 5/32 déjà mentionnés, mais la séritable journée mauvaise, de la semaine a été celle d'aujourd'hui qui nous a valu 15/32 de baisse, ce qui fait que, comme cloture, nous sommes tout simplement à 13/16 au-dessous de vendredi dernier. Les plus acharnés párini les baissiers n'en espéraient pas autant, mais on dirait que notre marché a tenu à donner une nouvelle preuve que tout se passait d'une façon extraordinaire chez nous cette année.

En effet, rien de nouveau, ni du dehors, di local, n'était, venu justifier cet état de choses, et à ceux qui voudraient l'attribuer à la situation de l'Américain nous répondrons que c'est justement au plus mauvais moinent de FAméricain que nous nous étions ie mienx tenus ici, tandis que c'est avec l'annonce de la reprise pour le dit coton et de l'amélioration du marché financier de New-York que la baisse s'est accentuée chez nous, Áussi, à notre avis, le seul fait qui a pu influencer la spéculation est la question des exportations, à moins que, comme d'autres le pensent, ce ne soient les nécessités pécuniaires qui ont attiré les ordres. de vente dont le résultat a' été, le désarroi auquel nous avons assisté ces jours derniers. · Car, pour ce qui est des exportations, malgré la diminution, prévne d'ailleurs, nous sommes restés de 3000 Billes au-dessus de l'anné dernière pour la même p riude et les 115 Balles sensées être les embarquements d'aujourd'hui, d'après les dounées de la Douane, ne prouvent nullement que nous sommes déjà tombés aux petits chiffres. . C'est toujours, il est vrai, un indice peu encourageant, mais combien de semaines n'avons-nous pas eues, qui ont tout aussi mal, coinmencé, mais qui ont fini avec des quantités régulières. - - Maintenant, en dehors de ce que nous venons d'exposer, il y a un autre, point que nous ne devons pas oublier et sur lequel nous avons - souvent insisté : * C''est la quantité de petits spéculateurs intéressrs à la hausse
On nous dira, mais le découvert qu'en faitesvous ? Le découvert existe incontestablement sur la vieille récolte ; mais est, on bör qu'il

H'étend au delà d'Alexandrie et qu'il est impor- tant 1 Tandis qu'au Caire tout le monde est . à la hausse et en fin de compte tout le monde n'est pas millionnaire et ne sait pas limiter ses * spéculations à ses moyens financiers ! C'est I que résidait le véritable danger et c'est des | réalisations du Caire précisément, qu'est venue la débandade d'hier.

Il est vrai que tout le monde ne pense pas de la même manière et qu'il reste la plupart * des gros'faiseurs de la capitale, mais le seul fait de ne pas avoir réagi.aujoutd'hui au plits fort de la baisse et avec la liquidation leur pendant sur la tête nous laisserait supposer qu'ils sont probablement surchargés. et qu'ils ne peuvent pas continuer à absorber tout ce qui est offert à la vente.

En somme, la situation actuelle de la vieille récolte' n'est pas brillante et ce ne sont pas les 13/16 de tallari de report de Mars à Mai payés de nouveau bier qui nous feront croire que la position est en train de s'améliorer ! Est-ce que tont, ce q i' s'est passé jusqu'ici sous ce rapport, a empêché le Mai de se rapprocher du Novembre 1 Il y a buit jours' l'écart était exactement de 2 tallaris et ce suit il n'est plus que de 1 3/4 et du pas dont nous marchons, il ne noúg faudrait que de deux à trois jours pour que Mai prennent détinitivement la place du Mars. C'est une ventualité que nous avons mise en vue depuis plusieurs semaines déjà et les évènements sont en train de prouver qne noua pe none étions pas trompés. D'après ce que nons voyons, il anffira de I quelques milliers de Cantars à la filière de d'emain, la dernière du mois, pour hâter l'accomplissement du fait.

Par la suite nons verrons le rapprochement | entre les deux récoltes s'accentuer, car pour le moment on n'aperçoit encore ancun signe du réveil de la demande de la part de la filature | ponr les mois rapprochés, seul fait qui pourrait aider au sauvetage partiel de la vieille récolte, qui se prête d'autant plus facilement aux attaques des baissiers- qu'en fin de compte la spéculation, pour.la plus grande partie de ce I qu'elle détient en contrat- Mai, a à faire à la marchandise effective, que les journées passent et que l'éch ance approche ! C'est vriment, triste de voir le Mai, de 24 tallaris, tomber a | 22 environ et cela après avoir payé 3 rep rts de 3 4 de tal ari ch cun en moyenne Quant aux fameuses réceptions de Mars, on ne voit I pis qu'en dehors de q elques arbi r gistes, il y |ait des exportate rs, à une seule exception près, qui prennent livraison du Mars Et encore ne s'agit-il que de quelques milliers de C ntars I qui ne peuvent rien changer à la situation.

La tenue du Novembre a été relativement meilleure que celle de la récolte actuelle, mais là aussi c'est la baisse qui est à enregistrer. Elle n'est pas dans les mêmes proportio s que le Mars, mais c'est encore en un demi tallari qu'elle se résume.

On a répandu le bruit, et c'est là un des motifs qui ont provoqué la baisse, qu'il y avait eu une résiliation avec la filat re de 6000 balles sur ia nouvelle r colte. Quoique tout soit possible, pour notre part nous n'y croyons pas; mais ce qui pourrait être affirmé, c'est l'abstention de la consommation de toute nouvelle | affaire, abstention peut-être plus complète sur (la prochaine récolte que sur l'octuelle

Du dehors, anoune nouvelle saillạnte pou|vant intéresser les cotons égyptiens. Par contre, pour ce quiest des Américains, nous avons eu le Census Bureal qui donne légrenage comme I étant de 13.291.000 balles, y compris les linters, mais sans autres détails permettant de suivre Price dans ses raisonnements, tendant à prouver qu'avec 13.300.000 balles, sans pr . judice du solde qui pourrait venir d'ici fin août, la récolte ne saurait être supérieure à 13.000.000 balles. La prochaine circulaire du leader actnel du parti de la hausse en Amérique devra être bien intéressante pour ne pas Ddire comique ! 1. En attendant, soit à cause de l'amélioration de la situation financière, soit que l'on consid re q e la dernièie bais e ait suffisamment escompte les effets du rapport, précité ou soit enfin, que la demande de la filature ne dis : continue pas, le lait est que ce n'est pas par de la baissé que les 13.29 :000 du Census Bureau ont été saluées.
Notre marché du disponible a ité presq e 'pul, mais comme de juste et comme nous

l'avons déjà mentionné, une grande partie de l'inaction ont dhe au marque de marchandise à la vente. Et une preuve de cette appr ciation. est à trouver dans le fait que les prix du spot ne sont plus aussi intimement liés aux fluctuations: des contrats, car tandis que ces derniers se présentai nt avec une perte de 15/32 au moment de l'établissement de la cote officielle de ce matin, les cours de vendredi dernier ont été maintenus intégralement et sur toute la ligne.

Comme d jà dit plus haut, les exportations de la semaine ont jeté du froid sur le marché, mais ce qui a le plus influencé, ce sont les embarquements de la première journée qui ont inspiré des craintes pour la semaine prochaine qui aura à comparer avec 15,000 balles l'année dernière. Il ne faut pourtant pas trop se fier aux apparences, l'année courante étant l'année aux surprises par excellence.

Le mouvement de la récolte nous d nne à cette date 1,004,000 cantars de pl. aq e l'année passée comme recettes à cette même date; 647 000 can ars comme surplus dans les exportations, se partageant en 84,000 Balles pour T'Angleterre, 25,000 pour le Continent et 28,000 pour l'Amérique et finalement un stock de 230,000 cantars supérieur à celui de 1906 à ce jour. Avec les recettes en vue d'ici la fin de la campagne, ces 230,000 cantarg représentent en fait le surplus dans nos ressources sur 1906 pour les cinq mois à venir, et comme l'année dernière nous avoris fini avee 220,000 cantars · de stock à nouveau, avec des exp ditione égali s pour le restant de la campagne nous devrons cloturer avec environ 450,000 cantars à reporter! La' perspective n'est guère alléchante si la filature ne nous vient pas en aide.

Liverpool a été peu actif pour les Egyptiens disponibles, mais pour ce qui est des prix, il n'y a ancune différence à relever pour le spot qui reste à. 1 3/8. Pour les futurs, par contre, le Mars, perd 8/64, à 'a cote de 11 6/64.

Les am ricains vont toujours leur petit train-train et les cours de clôture de ce soir ne nous montrent que 2 points de baisse pour le spot et 4 pour les futurs, la coté étant respectivement de 6 Ól pour la marchandise prête, 5.66 pour le Mai-Juin et 5.57' pour l'OctobreNovembre

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Les recettes ont été an-dessous des besoins de l'exportation, ce qui a contribué a" sontien des prix Le disponible a fini à P.T. 77. 77 et reste en bonne tei dance, sauf baisse du dehors, car il y aura de la demande pour la semaine pr chaine.

Les contrats ont présente un peu plus d'animation et l'Avril a touch le cours de PT 78 1/2 ; il clôture pourtant en réaction à P.T. 77 1 2. La dema de de Hull s'est réveillée ces jours derniers et l'Avril s'est trai é à £7 8 9. Il y a du 'ca me de nouveau cependant.
Les 8 mois ont haussé jusqu'a P.T. 68 3/4 et les prix restent fermes.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 22 mars. Toute l'attention de nos spéculateurs s'est concentrée cette semaine sur les Ritz Hotels, k Nile - Land, les Estates, l'United Lands, l'Arditi, la Levico, la Gabbari Land, les Nungovich, la Delta Land et le Comptoir. Les Ritz font un bond de 2 1/2 à 3 3/16. C'est 6 livres et 5,8 que gagne la Nile Land à 30 livres. La Gabbari Land est traitée à 10 et 11 livres, soit ayec 6 ou 7 livres de prime. L'Arditi, après avoir atteint 1 1/2, finit à 1 13/82 l'action et 26 la part de fondateur. La Levico s'inscrit à 1 11/32 l'action et 18 la part de fondateur. Après une poussée momentanée à 1 9/32, l'Un ted clôture à 1 5/32, acheteurs, Par contre, les Estates perdent 1/8 2 1'8, Je Delta Land 1/16 à 3 9/16, le Comptoir 1,8 7 1/16 l'action et 1 4 à 7 7,8 la part de fondateur Les Nungovich, après avoir touché le prix de 29 1/8, cloturent à 28 3/4, soit avec 1,8 seulement d'avance. Pendant ce temps, l'Agricole recule à 8 7/8 et la National Bank à 26 7/16, soit pour cette dernière près d'une livre de baisse. L'Obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien perd 5 fr. - 339, la Béhéra 1/2 a 39, et l'Union Foncière 1/16 à 5 15/16. L'Alexandria Water perd également 1/8 à 13 1/8, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire 4 fr. a 273, la Daïra Sanieh 1/8 à 15 7 8, les Privilégiées Bière d'Alexandrie 4 fr. à 222, l'AngloAmerican Nile 3/4 de livre à 4 5/8, la Building Lands 1/16 à 5 9,16, la Banque d'Orient 4 fr à 129, l'Auto-Transport 1/4 à 4, et la Soci té Electrique et Mécanique 1/4 à 4 1/2. En Tramways d'Alexandrie, tandis que la Privilégiée bénéficie de 2 fr., la Dividende recule de 15 fr. aux cours respectifs de 184 et 330. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Markets réac. tionnent à 25/6, l'Aboukir .. 40 -, les Cotton | Mills à 5/3, l'Hulpuan a 3/4 et la Land Investment and Building à 13 16, tandis que l'Investment (Abdy) reprend à 1 3/32, la Port Said Salt a 15/-, et la Levant à 7/8. La Cassa di Sconto est un peu mieux tenue à 231 l'ancienne, 227 1/2 la nouvelle et 217 la dernière émission, ainsi que le Banco di Roma A 114 Les Lots Turcs sont au contraire un pen plus faibles à 154, la Banque d'Athènes à 120, i Urbaine nouvelle à 6 13/16, et le Crédit I ranco-Egyptien à 5 31/32, vendeurg. Le reste de la cote est sans cbangement. Bien qu'il ne soit pas tu ujours aisé 'établir sos pr nosti, s en matière de bourse, cette tâche' est devenue depuis quelque temps impossible cause des manipulations incessantes de quel qués spéculateurs. On coucevra, en effet, qu'il n'est pas de notre ressort de prévoit les combinaisons plus ou moins compliquées au moyen desquelles certains groupes pro-, voquent des mouvements absolument inat-| tendam C'est, précisément parce que le secret est bien gardé sur ces manœuvres -qu'elles peuvent réussir. Aux intéressés de se tenir sur leur garde. Ce que nous pouvons faire au contraire, en connaissance de cause, c'est signaler l'exagération des mouvements soit à la hausse, soit à la baisse qui se produisent sur le bloc des titres classes et éprouvés, dont le revenu est connu aussi bien que leur stabilité et leurs chances de plus-value. Tous ces titres suivent en général un mouvement uniforme et ont des périodes de hausse, invariablement suivies de périodes de réaction ; mais ils ont cela de particulier que l'acheteur, revoit assez vite son prix d'achat, même lors qu'il a eu l'imprudence de s'engager au plus baut. | C'est ce qu'il ne risque pas de faire en co moment ci, puisque la plupart des titres en question sont tombés à un niveau qui constitue un placement avantageux. Il y a d'autant plus lieu de réagir contre la panique générale que les spectres agités par les buissiers, krach à New York, pénurie monétaire, excès de la | spéculation, s'évanouissent les uns après les a tres. On nous annonce, en effet, de Londres, que New-York s'est complètement ressaisi et qu'un mouvement intense est en perspective. En rejetant de ces nouvelles ce qu'elles peuvent avoir d'exagéré, nous ne voyons pas comment un krach américain porterait atteinte à des valeurs égyptiennes sagement administrées et solidement assises sur le rendement progressif du pays. La première assemblée générale de l'Union Foncière d'Egypte aura lieu mercredi prochain au si ge social à Alexandrie. Le coupon déclaré par le conseil d'administration sera seulement de 4 1/2 %, mais on sait déjà que les affaires de la société sont très prospères Si, parmi les terrains achetés, tous admir: blement situés et de premier ordre, peu ont été vendus jusqu'ici, ce n'est pas faute d'offres rémunératrices, car pour la plupart d'entre eux il s'est présente des ar heteurs à des prix laissant à la société un bénéfice de 60 à 100 %. C'est par ce qu'il | estime pouvoir trouver mieux encore que le conseil d'administration ne se presse pas de vendre. Le prix de la valeur étant seulement de 5 15/16-6, soit une livre au-dessus du pair, nous n'hésitons pas à en conseiller l'achat à nos lecteurs, comme une operation des plus avantageuses, soit comme sécurité soit comme chance de plus-value. Un autre titre qui se recommande à l'attention des capitalistes d'une façon toute particulière, c'est l'Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co dont le ours est tombé, à 3 livres, c'est-à- dire à une livre nu-dessous du pair Si pourtant les informations du consei,. d'administration sont exactes, et il est as-ez respectable (M. Willcocks et plusieurs notables indigènes de toute honoraburité en font partie) pour que nous nous en rapportions à ses assura, ces, la situation de la société est exceptionnellement progpère. Outre un excellent terrain de vaste étendue à Damanhour, la société a obtenu sous la protection du Gouvernerpent anglais une concession immense dans l'ile de Chypre aox conditions les plus avantageuses ; toujours sous la protection du gouvernement anglais, et avec une garantie a alogue à celle dont jouit ici l'Agricultural Bank, l'Allotment a lancé a Chypre une banque agricole qui est actuellement en pleine activité. Le secrétariat nous informait ces jours derniers qu'au cours du dernier trimestre les demandes d'emprunts adressées à la banque avaient été trois fois plus considérables que durant toute l'année précédente. Comme il n'y a pas lieu de suspectes ces affirmations, nous ne pouvons que recommander la valeur, aux capitalistes clair. voyants, qui d'ailleurs ne tarderont pas à être plus amplernent renseignés, puisque l'assemblée générale a lieu samedi prochain, 30 couՄանե Les Egyptian Estates viennent d'obtenir le décret khedivial d'autorisation pour la nouvelle société qu'ils viennent de créer sous le nom de "Cairo Estates Company." C'est une. soci té égyptienne au Capital de LE. 400.000, divisé en 100.000 actions de L.E. 4 chacune. Il n'y aura pas de parts de fondatenrs ni d'actions privilégiées. Le Conseil d'administration est ainsi composé : MM. Greville H. Palmer, Montagu Summers, George Nungovich, Alfred Curphey et Me Carton de Wiart. Ces noms sont assez connus pour que nous nous abste nions de tous 'cominenta res. 50.000 actions seront offertes en souscription publique do 26 au 28 mars.

Probably no other physician in the world has received such a volume of enthusiastic letters of thanks as Dr. Hartman for Peruns.

div.head: The Utmost Confidence in Pe.ru.na.

div.p: Miss Marie L. Meunier, 995 Ontario street, Montreal, P.Q., Can., writes: ml take pleasure la stating that I have been cured of catarrh by Peruna. This disease made my life miserable, especially lo the morning, when I bad to cough and spit and make every effort to clear my throat and ale passages. This remedy cured me promptly and I recommend it. most highly to persons afflicted with this terrible disease."

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”

div.head: LE GUIDE-HORAIRE.
div.p: Nous sommes priés L d'annoncer que Mr. E. Ravan, propriétaire de l'"Express-Publicité", est seul éditeur du "Guide-Horaire" de l'Egypte et du Soudar fourni officiellement par l'Administration des Chemins de fer. La quatrième édition du "Guide-Horaire" actuellement en préparation, paraltra le 1er Mai 1907. Le Guide Horaire" est un précieux intermédiaire de publicité méritant une attention toute particulière de la part des Banques, de l'industrie et du Commerce en général, à cause des avaritages incontestables qu'il offre sur les publications similaires, Mr. Jules Mignot, Directeur et Agent Général de l' "Express-Publicité", a seul qualité de traiter pour les insertions dans le "Guide-Horaire qui ne sont payables qu'après publica. tion et contre justificatif. 29701-10A-3

It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life.
